fields.description:
For the same image as seen in EUCA-7147, I tried to download and then unbundle it.  The unbundle fails on the decryption.

Firstly, download the image which was registered from the euca-bundle-instance output:

{code}
[root@emea-demo-01 admin]# euca-download-bundle -b windows_bundled -p windowsbundle.manifest.xml
{code}

try to unbundle it:

{code}[root@emea-demo-01 tmpGdfq4H]# euca-unbundle -m windowsbundle.manifest.xml
RSA operation error
140288951261000:error:0D0680A8:asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_CHECK_TLEN:wrong tag:tasn_dec.c:1320:
140288951261000:error:0D06C03A:asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_D2I_EX_PRIMITIVE:nested asn1 error:tasn_dec.c:832:
140288951261000:error:0D08303A:asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_TEMPLATE_NOEXP_D2I:nested asn1 error:tasn_dec.c:752:Field=n, Type=RSA
140288951261000:error:04093004:rsa routines:OLD_RSA_PRIV_DECODE:RSA lib:rsa_ameth.c:115:
140288951261000:error:04065084:rsa routines:RSA_EAY_PRIVATE_DECRYPT:data too large for modulus:rsa_eay.c:578:
RSA operation error
139995128973128:error:0D0680A8:asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_CHECK_TLEN:wrong tag:tasn_dec.c:1320:
139995128973128:error:0D06C03A:asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_D2I_EX_PRIMITIVE:nested asn1 error:tasn_dec.c:832:
139995128973128:error:0D08303A:asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_TEMPLATE_NOEXP_D2I:nested asn1 error:tasn_dec.c:752:Field=n, Type=RSA
139995128973128:error:04093004:rsa routines:OLD_RSA_PRIV_DECODE:RSA lib:rsa_ameth.c:115:
139995128973128:error:0407106B:rsa routines:RSA_padding_check_PKCS1_type_2:block type is not 02:rsa_pk1.c:190:
139995128973128:error:04065072:rsa routines:RSA_EAY_PRIVATE_DECRYPT:padding check failed:rsa_eay.c:653:
euca-unbundle: error: Failed to decrypt the bundle's encryption key.  Ensure the key supplied matches the one used for bundling.
{code}

I am using the same identity and keys that I used for both the bundle-instance, register and this unbundle attempt.
fields.summary: Cannot unbundle image which was bundled with euca-bundle-instance

comments.body:
The current implementation doesn't allow this. There's a ticket to refresh bundle-instance implementation (https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-6098), and IMO that can solve the problem. 

unbundle-image tries to decrypt the bundle with user's private key, and that works for ordinary bundles since the encryption used user's certificate. In the case of bundle-instance, the current implementation uses NC's cert to encrypt. So users can't decrypt them.

Yes, I think this will have to be a "Known Issue" for 3.4: "EMIs created with euca-bundle-instance operation cannot be unbundled with user's credentials. The workaround for Linux images is to launch an instance from the EMI and perform euca-bundle-volume in it."
Will this be addressed by the linked ticket?
What I mean to say is, will EUCA-6098 fix this?

[~lwade] yes I think so. However note that EUCA-6098 is not about fixing a particular bug, but more of feature improvements (I.e., reimplement bundle-instance almost entirely). So it will take some significant effort to address.
Thanks [~spark], just wondering if those changes will address the root issue here.

To comment on this again, with this ticket and EUCA-6098 we need to address the following use-case in the fix:

A user wants to move a cloud image between clouds.  To do this they want to bundle an instance and then download and unencrypt the bundle.   So a user would run the following commands to achieve this:

- euca-bundle instance
- euca-download-bundle
- euca-unbundle

... and be left with a image file which they can manipulate further or move to another cloud to bundle, upload and register.

Yes, that is a useful use-case, [~lwade]. We'll try to support it. Even though it won't have an equivalent in AWS. The AWS way, which works in Euca, too, is:

* euca-bundle-vol (inside the running instance)
* euca-upload-bundle (inside the running instance)
* euca-register
* euca-download-bundle
* euca-unbundle

Obviously more involved -- thus the desire to shorten it -- but more consistent between AWS and Euca.

Sorry, I meant to add that my example is specifically in regards to Windows instances but if we're support ec2-bundle-instance for Linux instance-store backed instances the same should work, no?  This workflow exists in AWS.

Oh, yeah, for Windows bundle-vol is not an option. I did not realize that the workflow you described is supported for Windows in AWS. Then we should definitely support that. (And, yes, that would apply to Linux IS instances in Euca, too.)

To be honest I've not tried a download of the Windows image bundle.  I'd imagine this can't be done due to licensing reasons, somehow.  However, for Eucalyptus this is fairly critical since we're within the corporate environment and this stuff is controlled.

Images created with this process are intentionally extractable only with the cloud's private key for exactly the reason you suggest.  When you're using Eucalyptus instead of EC2 that precise wording is crucial -- cloud administrators have access to the cloud's private key, making it possible to extract those bundles independently.  Simply fetch cloud-pk.pem from a CLC and pass it to euca-unbundle.

Super.  I guess this leads to the question; should we enable this workflow in future?  I believe we should.  We have many use cases where users are uploading their own images but wish to be able to modify and extract them from the cloud at any time (without having to contact their administrator).

We're constrained by the way bundles and X.509 credentials work when it comes to people's manually downloading and unbundling things, which makes this sound like an excellent import/export service use case.

Thanks, everyone, for chiming in! I am going to close this ticket as 'Won't Fix' because for 4.0 the system behaves as designed (and does not violate AWS compatibility). Which is to say: bundles created by 'euca-bundle-instance' can be downloaded and unbundled using cloud private key (cloud-pk.pem) and not with the key of the user who owns the instance and the resulting bundle. The reason is because the bundle is created on the back end, which does not have access to the user's cert in the current design. (The cert is not part of the request on AWS because such bundles -- of Windows instances -- aren't intended to be unbundle-able.) 

I don't think it's a bad idea to allow such workflow in Eucalyptus, but that will require a little bit of design and some cross-cutting implementation work. Perhaps an image export service is a good way to tackle this, perhaps simply adding user's cert as Euca-specific parameter to bundle-instance is a good one. I'd love to have a discussion about this and hopefully complete the work in the next release. (We'll have plenty of image-related work to complete then anyway.) Would someone like to file a feature request ticket?
